comment.author: 67908005@N02
comment._content: Named on sides as "Vestibule Sleeping Car" "Elsa". Maybe the Smithsonian (Washington DC USA) hold the original photo / card ? They hold many of Pullman's records: americanhistory.si.edu/archives/AC1175.html . This looks as though the location was Pullman Factory, Illinois, USA. See: "Remains of Pullman Factory" for a view of the factory building, albeit from a different angle, together with a Pullman (Chicago) Historical District placard, both of which give tend to identificy the factory location. The company built a company town, also called "Pullman", Illinois on 4,000 acres (16 km²), 14 mi (23 km) south of Chicago in 1880. The town, entirely company-owned, provided housing, markets, a library, churches and entertainment for the 6,000 company employees and an equal number of dependents. Source : Wikepedia & Pullman history. The company town is now a district of Chicago.

comment.author: 67908005@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/hpeters/] myhappypenguin Your link provides a very useful description of the provenance of HX1006. Many thanks. However, I am sure this particular coach is not HX1006, at Thirlmere - HX1006 is recorded as having open platforms, this is clearly a closed vestibule coach. This coach ('car' in American terminology) is clearly Pullman built, in the USA, (the main factory was in Chicago, Illinois, but there was also a Detroit faciltiy); whilst HX1006 was "built" in NSW, according to info supplied to this time in the group. Search the Clerestory Group for HX1006 at Thirlmere, click here....

comment.author: 73199923@N00
comment._content:
"...The negotiations which have been proceeding for the last fortnight or so, between Mr. William Pullman and the Railway Commissioners of New South Wales for the introduction of the Pullman Palace Cars upon the railways of this colony have, we are informed has been practically completed.

Mr. Pullman had intended to proceed to America by tho outgoing mail steamer, but he finds it necessary to defer his departure for a month period which will be spent principally in Sydney and Melbourne. Mr.Pullman's contract with the Commissioners is to provide 15 cars in all, 6 being of the description known as hotel cars, and. 9 of the kind known as " sleepers " Each hotel car will dine 46 persons at a sitting, and each sleeper afford accommodation for 32 passengers. The cars will be of the type known as the Pullman Vestibule Limited. The hotel cars, which are to be elaborately furnished, are said to cost £6000 each, and the sleeping cars £4000 .each.

The vehicles to be supplied to this colony will correspond in character with those running on the railways between New York and Chicago and will be furnished with an abundance of contrivances for securing the comfort of passengers. Not only is there to be a dining saloon, but almost all the other appointments of a well designed hotel, including drawing rooms, a social hall, furnished with a piano, smoking-rooms, bathrooms, lavatories, etc. The train will, be lighted throughout with electricity. Tho Commissioners.propose to have the Pullman cars in October next to convoy passengers to tho Melbourne races. Mr. Pullman however, expects to have all the vehicles in Sydney by next August.

Passengers will welcome tho prospect of being able to enjoy the luxury of the luxury of the biggest name of the Pullman Palace Car, and their joy will be greatly increased when they realised - as we are informed by Mr. Pullman will be the case - that instead of having to pay 12s. 6d. each for a sleeping, berth to Albury they will not be required to pay more, than 8s a reduction of 4s 6d. The object of the reduced charge is to induce a much larger number of people than is now the case to patronise the cars..." Sydney Morning Herald  22 January 1890

comment.author: 67908005@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/hpeters/] myhappypenguin The initial Pullman coaches imported into the UK, in 1874, by the Midland Railway (MR), were assembled (my phraseology) in the UK but manufactured in the US. The assembly was conducted by the Pullman Company who established sheds in Derby, alongside the main MR railway works. Source : American Pullman Cars of the Midland Railway. Note: It is not exactly clear how much local content was used in the assembly, as the phrase "crates of parts for the vehicles, supplied from the Detroit workshops of the Pullman Palace Car Company in knocked-down condition, were arriving [by the end of 1873] at Derby.... for re-assembly" (p14, ibid). I wonder therefore whether Eveleigh in fact assembled the coaches, e.g. HX1006 as distinct from fully manufactured. If so, that would be similar to the precedent set in the UK? Looks like some useful research you have performed, but may need a further cross-check, before assumptions (at least on my part) are confirmed.

comment.author: 73199923@N00
comment._content: As you can read from this letter to the editor importing coaches was not popular trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/printArticlePdf/13757803/6?print=n

comment.author: 67908005@N02
comment._content: Thanks but one albeit vociferous objector doesn't mean that the policy of possibly a few days earlier was reversed, even if there might be a polictical party supporting the issue raised. This, however, is NOT a forum for political matters. Doubtless, even at that time, there were such things as patents, and copyrights in names etc., hence the coaches you referred to be ing described as "Pullman style". Thus the purpose of this group is to document specific railway artefacts, of whatever manufacture / build or assembly, as the name describes - which are mostly late 19th century, early 20th century - and is it turns out given continued manufacture in the US, mid 20th century as well! So, the question remains : Assembly versus Manufacture? [http://www.flickr.com/photos/73199923@N00] if you are resident in Australia, perhaps you have better access or research facilities than I to delve further and report definitively. Some of the articles you have provided links to refer to books eqivalent to the UK one I have cited, plus there are the museum and state archival authorites. Hopefully they are close at hand?

comment.author: 67908005@N02
comment._content: Meantime, the RTM Asset Manager has conformed overnight that the Thirlmere vehicles were manufactured by the NSW Railways works at Eveleigh. So all of this discussion detracts from the postcard above, which is of historical significance to the George Pullman companies alone, and which does not, technically have a bearing on the particular Australian preserved rake introduced into the discussion here, which have their own photos in the clerestory group, elsewhere.
